title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 specifies the coin's design and purpose. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins issued under this Act shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin will have a designated value, an inscription of the year '1995', and a design representing the value of the coin. The coins issued under this Act shall have a designated value, the year '1995' inscribed, and include the words 'Liberty', 'In God We Trust', 'United States of America', and 'E Pluribus Unum'. They will be legal tender as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of SEC-5 coins. Quality of coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint Facility - No more than 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act. Period of Issuance - The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on. The Act was in effect from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. The Act was in effect from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. SEC-6-SALE OF COINS. The Act authorized coins to be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, including surcharges. The cost of designing and issuing the coins is also included in the price. Bulk sales are also allowed by the Secretary. Bulk sales, prepaid orders, and surcharge requirements are outlined in the Act. The Secretary can offer bulk sales at a reasonable discount, accept prepaid orders for authorized coins, and impose a surcharge on all sales. Under this subsection, a reasonable discount is required. A surcharge of $10 per coin is mandatory for all sales. General waiver of procurement regulations. No provision of law governing procurement or public contracts applies to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section relieves any person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. Audits are also required. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. The Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins includes a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions of the coin value and year "1995". Each coin minted under this Act will have inscriptions of the coin value, year "1995", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one designated Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $10, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge. Sales under this subsection shall be at a reasonable discount and include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. All surcharges from coin sales under this Act are promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the National Fund's expenditures related to these payments.
